data.title: should we prompt to "save as" on close of a deleted file?
data.body:
Testing: #23242

* autosave off 
* `"workbench.editor.closeOnFileDelete": false`

1. create a new file (e.g. `test.md`)
2. make some changes, save to disk
3. delete from disk (using Finder)

Result: you see the "(deleted from disk)" note in the tab.  This is goodness.

If i make an edit to the file to dirty it, then click on the "x" then i get prompted to save, this is goodness. 

However, if I don't make any changes the file then click on the "x" to close, I'm not prompted and all of that content in the file is gone. It feels like data loss. How bad would it be to prompt the user in this scenario? maybe the file was removed from disk accidentally...

data.title: Copy in settings vs keybindings editor
data.body:
Testing #23287

Copy action in settings editor, copies and pastes the settings to user's settings
Copy action in keybindings editor, only copies, user has to open the keybindings.json file and paste it themselves.

User Experience is not consistent

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (a35c7da7b8f324c1e8cc7830173418e392542f6d, 2017-03-28T12:40:24.966Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In a .ts file Ctrl + Space
2. Left mouse click a proposal
3. -> Not inserted.

Not sure how relevant that is. 1.10.2 inserts the proposal.

data.body:
Testing #23287 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/24427048/7e392180-13be-11e7-9714-5c706625724d.png)

The text is a bit off.

May be

- Press desired key combination and ENTER, ESCAPE to cancel
- Press desired key combination and ENTER or ESCAPE to cancel

data.title: Edit, Copy, Remove, Reset options in a single menu for keybindings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #23287

In the settings editor, the "edit" icon gives options like "Copy" and in case of enum or boolean, gives you options for the same.

Why not use the same approach for keybindings and combine Edit, Copy, Remove, Reset options in a single menu?

The right-click to copy, remove, reset is not discoverable

data.title: How to get default shortcut back after removing a keybinding
data.body:
Testing #23287 

- Right click on any of the default keybindings and press "Remove keybinding"

Now there is no way to get that keybinding back.

I'd expect the "Reset keybinding" option to be available

data.title: Debugger does not work with electron v1.6.x
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Just update to electron v1.6.2 (latest version as of 3/28/17)
2. Place a breakpoint and it will hit the breakpoint although I don't see the stack trace or the yellow debugger line.
3. Here is the error description under the CALL STACK sub window: `No call stack available (vscode_backtrace: Internal error: TypeError: undefined is not a function)`
4. This happens with both electron 1.6.1 & 1.6.2

data.title: Indicator that the keybinding has args
data.body:
Testing #23287 

Currently, you cannot see if there are any args for a keybinding.
Agreed, that it might be too much info to show in a simple view.

Therefore, I suggest to just have an indicator somehow to indicate that the keybinding has args

On another note, wouldnt this information be more important that the "source" we show in the current design?

data.title: Inconsistent terminology for "finding additional items in the marketplace"
data.body:
Testing #21633

We have inconsistent terminology for prompting the user to search the marketplace for additional things. For example:

* Debug Menu: "Install More Debuggers..."
* Preferences | Color Theme: "Find more in the Marketplace..."
* Preferences | File Icon Theme: "Find more in the Marketplace..."

Changing "Install More Debuggers" to "Find more in the Marketplace..." does not make sense because there is no context for "more".  "Find more debuggers in the Marketplace..." is simply too long for the menu.  A better solution I think would be to change these across the board. 

I'm not a fan of the word "more" in this context as it feels very informal, so I suggest the following:

Install Additional Debuggers...
Install Additional Color Themes...
Install Additional File Icon Themes...

data.title: Theming: cannot override color that is set via registerThemingParticipant
Processes running in the built-in terminal do not get ended when VSCode restarts itself
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start a process in the Terminal
2. Update or install a new extension
3. Click "Restart" when it is done installing.
4. When Code restarts, it will not end the process you started.

EDIT: I checked to make sure that a closed terminal window will successfully stop and processes it has started, just in case. That works as intended.

UPDATE: Cannot reproduce on Linux. Following my instructions results in the process being closed successfully when restarting VSCode for an extension update. Tried on Ubuntu 16.04 with the same VSCode version.

data.title: Misalignment of method parameters located on separate lines
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

**Current Format**

```typescript
this.authService.resetPassword(payload)
    .map((data: { message: string }) => data.message)
    .subscribe(
    (message: string) => this.onResetPassword(message),
    (error: any) => console.error(error)
    );
```

**Expected Format**

```typescript
this.authService.resetPassword(payload)
    .map((data: { message: string }) => data.message)
    .subscribe(
        (message: string) => this.onResetPassword(message),
        (error: any) => console.error(error)
    );
```

data.title: Terminating task in terminal closes the terminal
data.body:
Test #23279

When we terminate the task in the terminal, the terminal window is disposed. Then users have no way to see the output of the task again.

data.title: Parameter Name Not Highlighted in JSDoc If No Type Specified
data.body:
The parameter name in the JSDoc is not highlighted if the type is not specified in the JSDoc. I don't want to specify the types in the JSDoc, because they are all specified in the function signature because I am developing in typescript. It would like the syntax highlighting to automatically highlight the first string after the `@param` tag if no type is specified. Ideally the highlight would be the same if there was a type specified or if there wasn't.

You can see in the screenshot below, `var1` has the proper highlighting because it has a type. `var2` is not highlighted at all.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1285448/24419774/2ee996b4-13a5-11e7-8850-45f2ae2470d6.png)


- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create JSDoc for function
2. Don't add types for the params in the documentation
3. Notice there is no syntax highlighting on the variable name.

Requested Behavior:
Automatically highlight the first string after the `@param` tag if no type is specified in the JSDoc

data.title: Can launch multiple instances of a compound debug config
data.body:
- Set up a compound launch config
- Launch it
- Click the launch button again in debug viewlet, and it launches the same configs again

This isn't allowed with individual launch configs

data.title: Emmet : load snippets from the user snippets folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win 10 pro x64 (french)

Currently, AFAIK the only way to load custom **emmet** snippets is to play with the absolute `emmet.extensionsPath`  user setting and put our custom files here.

It would be awesome that by default **VS Code** looks for a file like

    %APPDATA%\Code\User\snippets\snippets-emmet.json

and that **VS Code** helps to create this file with `workbench.action.openSnippets` when asking for language: **emmet**.

Thus all settings will stay in the user **Code** settings directory. It would make the process cleaner, easier and **emmet** custom snippets could be back up along the others **Code** settings.

data.title: Git clone authentication not working
data.body:
Testing for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23305

- VSCode Version: Insiders Latest
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type Git Clone into the command palatte
2. Clone a repository that I need auth for (in my example I used vscode-distro)

I expect to see affordance to enter my credentials. 
Actual: I saw an error message and no affordance. 

Note that I tried for both ssh and https clone. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/24418841/31d19bcc-13a2-11e7-857c-ce8b04aee2f3.png)

- VSCode Version: Insiders latest

2. Open the command palatte and choose Git: Stage File
